entry.title: Gym Workout
entry.summary:
Weeks 1 to 3

Day 1

  1. Squats 5x15,12,10,8,6
  2. Bent Over Rows 5x12,10,8,6,6
  3. Bench Press 5x15,12,10,8,6
  4. Overhead Press 5x12,10,8,6,6
  5. External Rotations 3x12*
  6. Seated Calf Raises 3x15
  7. Mountain Climbers 3x30 seconds
  8. Planks 3x30 seconds

Day 2

  1. Deadlift 5x15,12,10,8,6
  2. Kneeling Landmine Press 5x15,12,10,8,8
  3. Alt. Arnold Press 5x12,10,8,8,6
  4. Alt. Front Lunge 5x10
  5. Dumbbell Pullovers 3x15
  6. Weighted Crunches 3x15 (feet on wall)
  7. Side Planks 3x30 seconds

Day 3

  1. Front Squat 5x15,12,10,8,6
  2. T-Bar Row 5x12,10,8,8,6
  3. Dips 5x15
  4. Upright Row 5x15,12,10,8,8
  5. Glute Bridges (weighted) 3x10
  6. Standing Calf Raises 3x15
  7. Russian Twists 3x30 (15 each side)

entry.title: Primal Blueprint: Food To Avoid
entry.summary:
The primal blueprint: What Food To Avoid

Avoid All Grains

  • Grains offer a great majority of their calories in the form of carbs
  • Most grains contain phytates that bind to important minerals making them more difficult to abosrb
    • calcium, magnesium and zinc are examples of such minerals.
  • Some grains contain gluten, which tends to trigger an auto-immune response due to it closely mimicing viruses.
  • Grains contain high levels of mild plant toxins called lectins.

Grains To Avoid

  1. Wheat
  2. Rice
  3. Oats
  4. Cornmeal
  5. Barley

Avoid Polyunsaturated Fats (PUFAs)

PUFAs To Avoid

  1. Canola Oil
  2. Margerine
  3. Corn, safflower, sunflower, soybean and cottonsead oil
  4. Vegetable shortening

Avoid Trans And Partially Hydrogenated Fats

Partially Hydrogenated, Hydrogenated and Trans fats are evil. Avoid at all costs. They are found in most processed foods, including:

Trans and Hydrogenated Fats To Avoid

  1. Frozen dinners
  2. Candy
  3. Packaged snacks (crackers, chips and cookies)
  4. Peanut butter

Avoid Legumes

Legumes have significant levels of carbs. Most legumes are non-digestible/toxic to mammals, and need to be altered (cooked) for consumption.

Legumes To Avoid

  1. Alfalfa
  2. Beans
  3. Lentils
  4. Peanuts
  5. Peas
  6. Soy products

entry.title: Primal Blueprint: Food To Eat
entry.summary:
Primal Blueprint Eating Pyramid

Meat, Fowl and Fish

Fish

Fish are a rich source of Omega-3 fatty acids

Farmed Fish

Farmed Fish To Eat

  1. Fresh water coho Salmon
  2. Barramudi, catfish, crayfish and tilapia.
  3. Trout farmed in Canada or USA.
  4. Shell fish

Avoid farmed Atlantic salmon.

Vegetables

Vegetables To Eat

  1. Avocado
  2. Beets
  3. Broccoli
  4. Brussels Sprouts
  5. Carrots
  6. Cauliflower
  7. Eggplant
  8. Garlic
  9. Kale
  10. Onion
  11. Red bell pepper
  12. Spinach
  13. Yellow squash

Coconut Products

Use Coconut Products

  1. Coconut oil
  2. Coconut milk
  3. Coconut butter
  4. Coconut water
  5. Cocnut flakes

Medium Fatty Acids

Coconuts are an excellent source of medium fatty acids (very difficult to find in other foods)

  • Offers protection against heart disease, cancer, diabetes extract

Snacks

Farmed Fish To Eat

  1. Biltong
  2. Celery (enjoy with some cream cheese)
  3. Cottage cheese (enjoy with nuts, berries, balsamic vinegar etc)
  4. Dark chocolate
  5. Fish (canned tuna)
  6. Fresh berries (raspberries, blueberries, blackberries, strawberries)
  7. Hard-boiled eggs (sprinkle some salt and olive oil)
  8. Macadamia nuts
  9. Olives

Fruits

Some fruits should be eaten in moderation due to high fructose. Look for fruits that:

  1. High in anti-oxidants
  2. Have a low Total Metabolic FructoseL11

Note: Avoid fruit juice - it is high in sugar, and low in macro nutrients

Best Fruits To Eat

These fruits are high anti-oxidant, low glycemic, low TMF

  1. All berries (strawberries, blueberries, blackberries etc)
  2. Most pitted fruits (cherries, peaches, apricots)
  3. Avocados
  4. Casaba melon
  5. Lime and Lemon
  6. Tomato
  7. Guava

Good Fruits To Eat

These fruits are lower anti-oxidant, higher glycemic, medium TMF

  1. Apples
  2. Bananas
  3. Cantaloupe
  4. Grapefruit
  5. Kiwi
  6. Pomegranate

Moderate These Fruits

These fruits are low anti-oxidant, high glycemic, higher TMF

  1. Dates
  2. Dried fruits
  3. Grapes (all types of grapes)
  4. Mangoes
  5. Melons
  6. Nectarines
  7. Oranges
  8. Papayas
  9. Pineapples
  10. Plums
  11. Tangerines

Herbs And Spices

These are great - eat as much as you want

Nuts And Seeds

Should be ground up and added to salads etc - but don't overdo it!

Links

  1. http://thepaleodiet.com/fruits-and-sugars/
  1. A measure of how much fructose a particular fruit has ↩

entry.title: Gym Exercises
entry.summary:
Lower Body

Deadlift

To Begin

  1. Feet slightly wider than hip width, toes pointing out.
  2. Hands just outside legs.
  3. Shoulder blades directly over the bar.

Movement

  1. Keep chest high.
  2. Keep hips out.
  3. Back erect with very slight arch.
  4. Bar must roll up the shins and stay in line with legs.
  5. When reaching mid-way point of lift, push hips outward.
  6. Hold for two seconds.
  7. Return bar to gound, pushing hips inwards, and slightly bending the knees.

Avoid This

  1. Do not arch the back by letting the chest drop and shoulders go slack.
  2. Hips must always be higher than your knee - never let it drop below the knee.
  3. Do not lean backwards or forwards throughout the movement - keep it straight.

Front Squat

To Begin

  1. Feet slightly wider than shoulder width (so there is space to squat)

Movement

  1. Keep chest up.
  2. Keep core tight.
  3. Squat to at least parallel to the floor (can go below parallel, as long as chest is up)

Avoid This

Glute Bridges

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Lunge

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Standing Calf Raise

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Squat

To Begin

  1. Feet: Shoulder width apart.
  2. Toes: at a comfortable outwards pointing position.
  3. Rest Bar on upper shoulders

Movement

  1. Keep chest up.
  2. Lower body as if going to sit in a small chair.
  3. Stop when hips are lower than knees.
  4. While putting pressure on the heels, lead with chest while using glutes to rise.

Avoid This

  1. Heels: must be firmly on the ground throughout the movement
  2. Knees: make sure they don't track inwards.
  3. Do not place bar at the base of kneck – keep it at the upper trap

Upper Body

Arnold Press

To Begin

  1. Place weights on your upper legs - pump up legs to start with weights.
  2. Start with palms facing in, drop elbows so dumbbells are facing chest.

Movement

  1. Push dumbbells apart, rotating arms forward.

Avoid This

  1. Arms leaning forward - keep forearms upright.
  2. Focus all effort on shoulder, do not make a big wrist movement.

Bench Press

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Bent Over Rows

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Dips

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Dumbbell Pullover

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

External Rotations

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Landmine Chest Press

To Begin

  1. Start on knees, about shoulder width apart.
  2. Grab barbell right at the end, clasp both hands together to make a solid base.
  3. Bring it right below the chin.
  4. Lean slightly towards the bar.
  5. Keep the back straight.
  6. Chest up, shoulders tucked in together, and elbows tucked in.

Movement

  1. Press to get the full extension of the arms, sqeezing chest the entire way.
  2. Bring bar down slowly.

Avoid This

Overhead Press

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

Russian Twist

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

T-Bar Row

To Begin

  1. Feet shoulder width apart.

Movement

Avoid This

Upright Row

To Begin

  1. Feet shoulder width apart.

Movement

  1. Pull elbows up.

Avoid This

Weighed Crunch

To Begin

Movement

Avoid This

entry.title: Primal Blueprint Eating Philosophy
entry.summary:
Insulin

Insulin is vital for survival. Cell receptors use insulin as a key to unlock pores with the membrane of each cell. It's an elegant way to eliminate excess glucose from the bloodstream (which is highly toxic) which is then stored as glycogenL1 (glycogen is used as fuel) for a later date.

Excess Insulin

Excessive inslulin is bad!

  • Muscles and liver are not able to store high amounts of glycogen.
  • Excess glucose not used in "real-time" (i.e. during exercise) get converted into triglycerides and stored in fat cells.
  • High blood insulin level \(\implies\) the fat cells that store excess glucose also stores the fat of of your most recent meal.
  • Excess insulin is pro-inflammatory.
  • High insulin levels leads to insulin resistance:
    • Cell receptors become desensitized to insulin.
  • Moderate insulin levels leads to insulin sensitivity:
    • Liver and muscles are more effective at absorbing nutrients transported by insulin.

Excess Insulin And Heart Disease

  • Insulin promotes platelet adhesiveness (sticky platelets clot more easily).
  • Insulin promotes the conversion of macrophages (a type of white blood cell) into foam cells. These are the cells that fill with cholesterol and accumulate in arterial walls.
  • Insulin reduces blood levels of nitric oxide (a compound that relaxes the arterial wall lining) causing arteries to become more rigid. This increases blood pressure.

Insulin Resistant Consequences

  1. More glucose stays in blood. This is bad, glucose is toxic.
  2. More insulin is produced as a result of the elevated levels of glucose in the blood.
  3. Fat cells can't release their stored energy into the bloodstream since insulin keeps the "fat locked inside"
  4. Fat cells get bigger (i.e. you gain weight).

Insulin And Excercise

  • Excercise creates insulin sensitivity:
    • Exercise empties muscles and liver of glyocgen.
    • Insulin will then transport nutrients to liver and muscles instead of going to fat.

Cholesterol

Convential wisdom says you must lower your cholesterol intake. This is not true: The Framingham Heart StudyL2 totally refutes this. Study director Dr William Catelli1 summarized the issue:

Serum cholesterol is not a strong risk factor for heart disease

Study's highlights:

  • There is no correlation between dietary cholesterol and blood cholesterol levels.
  • Framingham residents who ate the most cholesterol, saturated fats and total calories weighed the least and were the most physically active.

Lipoproteins

Cholesterol is fat-soluble (i.e. it does not disolve in water), so in order to travel in the "water blood environment", it carried by special particles called lipoproteinsL4.

3 Important Lipoproteins

  1. VLDL - Very low density lipoproteins
  2. LDL - Low density lipoproteins
  3. HDL - High density lipoproteins <= good cholesterol

VLDL

  • VLDL are manufactured in the liver in the presence of high levels of triglycerides.
    • Therefore they comprise 80% triglycerides and very little cholesterol
  • Once triglycerides have been deposited, their size decreases and they convert into on of two types of LDL carrying mostly cholesterol:
    1. Large fluffy LDLs
    2. Small dense LSLs

LDL

  • Large fluffly "boyant" LDL are generally harmless (even at high levels).
  • Small dense LDL are extremely dangerous and cause heart disease
    • Small dense LDLs result when there are excessive triglycerides in the blood,

Small dense LDL result from high levels of carbs:

$$ \text{Carbs }\rightarrow\text{ Insulin }\rightarrow\text{ Triglycerides }\rightarrow\text{ VDL }\rightarrow\text{ Small Dense LDLs} $$

HDL

  • Good cholesterol
  • Cleans up any damages or oxidized cholesterol
  • Removes small dense LDLs

Increase HDL by exercising and consuming saturated fat.

Oxidation

Lipoproteins, if oxidized become damaged and are dangerous. Oxidation can happen for multiple reasons:

  • High intake of unstable polyunsaturated fats (PUFAs) from vegetable oils.
  • Reduction of natural antioxidants.
  • Low level of HDL.
  • Small dense LDLs do not bind as easily to the LDL receptors on muscles and fat cells.

AtherosclerosisL5 occurs in the arteries and not the veins because venous blood has little oxygen.

Oxidation and inflammation has little to do with total cholesterol (or even total LDL cholesterol) and is instead the result of the oxidation of a small fraction of the total amount of LDL - the small dense LDL particles.

Blood Tests

Most common blood tests do not distinguish between the benign "fluffy" LDL (sometimes called pattern A) and the small dense particles (sometimes called pattern B).

Here are some good articles:

  • How to interpret cholesterol testsL6
  • How to interpret advanced cholesterol testsL7
  • The straight dope on cholesterol: 10 things you need to know
    • part 1L8
    • part 2L9

What to measure in a blood test

  1. C-Reactive Protein (Hs-CRP) - produced as an immune system response. High levels associated with increased risk of heart attack.
  2. Lp2A - Key inflammation marker associated with small dense LDL
  3. A1c (Estimated average glucose) - Measures how much glucose is attached to hemoglobin molecule. Much better than common blood glucose reading.
  4. Fasting Blood Insulin Levels - High fasting insulin levels are indicitive of prediabetic conditions.

Macro Nutrients

There are three major macro nutrients:

  1. Protein
  2. Carbohydrate
  3. Fat

Protein

Optimal protein intake is 0.5 to 1.0 gram of protein per pound of lean body mass per day:

Calculate Lean Body Mass

  1. First, determine total weight and percentage of body fat.
  2. Multiply total weight by percentage of body fat to get your fat weight.
  3. Subtract fat weight from total body weight to get lean body mass.

Eating protein:

  • If exercising and a no low carb diet2, protein will go towards repair or building cell walls.
  • If there is not much insulin in the blood, the protein cannot easily be stored as fat and so the body is forced to raise the metabolic rate and increasing ketone production.

Carbohydrates

Carbohydrates control insulin; insulin controls fat storage

  • Only used for fuel.
  • All forms of carbs are eventually converted to glucose:
  • A limited amount of glucose will be stored as glycogen in muscles in liver.
  • Most glucose gets converted to fatty acids and stored in fat cells.
  • It's the job of insulin to take glucose out of the blood stream (glucose is toxic).

Unless one depletes lots of glycogen every day, there is no reason to consume high levels of carbs: * Carbs are not essential in our diets (proteins and fats are essential).

Daily Carb Intake

  • 0-50 grams: Ketosis and accelerated fat burning.
  • 50-100 grams: Primal sweetspot = effortless weight loss.
  • 100-150 grams: Primal blueprint maintenance range.
  • 150-300 grams: Steady insiduous weight gain.
  • 300 grams and more: Danger zone.

Fat

Consuming ample healthy fats is good] (this goes against conventional wisdom):

  • Ingesting fats makes you feel full (unlike carbs).
  • Fats have little or no impact on glucose levels (and therefore insulin)
    • Fats takes far longer than carbs to metabolize => deeper longer lasting satisfaction
  • The nurses health studyL11 concluded that total fat intake is not statistically correlated to heart disease.

Good Fats

Saturated and Omega 3 fats are healthy fats:

  • Omega 3L12 - found in fishy oils. The optimum ratio between Omega-6:Omega-3 is out of balance
    • Decrease Omega-6, increase Omega-3. The ratio should ideally be 2:1
  • Saturated FatsL13 - found in red meat.

Bad Fats

  • Omega 6L14 - fats in processed foods (omega 6 is needed to live, but ratio between omega 3 is scewed in modern diets).
  • Partially hydrogenated and trans fatsL15 - made by heating and chemically treating vegetable/seed oils to become solid. These fats are evil - avoid at all costs.

Carbs Make Fats Look Bad

Fats are calorically dense. If eaten with carbs, the insulin from the carbs will result in making one fat.

Ketones - The Fourth Fuel

Ketones3 are a by product of the fatty acid fuel used by the liver to extract glucose from proteins. It is an energy rich form of fuel that is both safe and desirable to use.

  • Ketones can't be stored like fat or glycogen - they just circulate the blood stream where they can be used by any cell.
  • Ketosis is the scientific name for when ketones accumulate in the body and can be used for energy.

Links

  1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycogen
  2. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Framingham_Heart_Study
  3. http://www.proteinpower.com/drmike/cardiovascular-disease/framingham-flip-flop/
  4. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipoprotein
  5. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atherosclerosis
  6. http://www.marksdailyapple.com/how-to-interpret-cholesterol-test-results/#axzz3ZB2yhrJh
  7. http://www.marksdailyapple.com/how-to-interpret-advanced-cholesterol-test-results/#axzz3ZB8x2c4p
  8. http://www.marksdailyapple.com/the-straight-dope-on-cholesterol-10-things-you-need-to-know-part-1/#axzz3ZB8x2c4p
  9. http://www.marksdailyapple.com/the-straight-dope-on-cholesterol-10-things-you-need-to-know-part-2/#axzz3ZB8x2c4p
  10. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atkins_diet
  11. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nurses%27_Health_Study

  13. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturated_fat
  14. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omega-6_fatty_acid
  15. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trans_fat
  16. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ketone_bodies#Impact_upon_pH

  2. For example, the Atkins DietL10. ↩
  3. They are actually called Ketone BodiesL16 ↩
